Award.AwardTitle: The Second NSF International Workshop on Sustainable Smart Cities - Egypt
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will support a workshop on Sustainable Smart Cities that will bring together decision making, research, and practitioner communities from the U.S. and Egypt to discuss the opportunities for developing and implementing sustainable urban development programs. The workshop will include approximately 50 carefully selected participants including 10 from the US, 5 from Europe, 30 from Egypt, and 5 from elsewhere in the Middle East and will take place in ~January 2019.

Research on sustainable urban infrastructure and living is urgently needed as the pace of urbanization continues to increase. Some estimates suggest that by 2050 70% of the world's population will live in cities, and already approximately 80% of the US population lives in urban areas. Cities consume a tremendous share of resources like water and energy for which demand globally is only increasing. Urbanization is increasing most rapidly in developing countries, making the topic of sustainable cities particularly valuable for collaboration between US and developing country scientists. Egypt is a particularly valuable location for this meeting, with Cairo facing some of the greatest urban infrastructure challenges of any city in the world and a new Egyptian capital under development east of Cairo.

The main goals of the workshop are to:
1) Explore how synergistic relationships between government, researchers, and practitioners can promote sustainable urban development;
2) Bring together the decision making, research, and practitioner communities from the U.S. and Egypt to identify and prioritize sustainability programs that address regional needs;
3) Identify specific objectives, decision criteria, and performance metrics to help decision makers
prioritize and evaluate sustainability projects;
4) Identify mutually beneficial research and training initiatives;
5) Identify lessons learned that can help the U.S. to apply similar practices at home and abroad.

Specifically, the workshop will offer a platform for sharing experiences and best practices in:
1) Economic transformation of cities;
2) Urban infrastructure;
3) Science, technology, and innovation for sustainable urbanization;
4) Health and well-being of citizens.

The overarching topic and selected themes are timely. Research efforts are underway in the US and around the world to find ways for cities to operate and grow that are efficient, attractive and economical while also supporting the needs of residents. This workshop will bring together experts from the US, Egypt, the rest of the Middle East/North Africa (MENA), and Europe to share results, coordinate new collaborative research endeavors, identify criteria for regional projects and priorities for new programs, and identify lessons for the US and developed countries to apply at home. These efforts are likely to be valuable in the US, in Egypt, and around the world.

Funding for this project is provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering through the US-Egypt Joint Fund.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2nd Sustainable Smart Cities International Workshop was organized to promote interdisciplinary collaboration and the exchange of knowledge related to advancing sustainable urbanization in arid regions. The broad goal was to bring together decision making, research, and practitioner communities from the U.S., U.K., and Egypt to facilitate open discussions and exchange of knowledge related to the challenges of advancing sustainable smart cities and the role of national and local governments in those efforts. This event helped to establish future directions of research at the global level and enhance the potential for collaboration between researchers and practitioners in the U.S. and Egypt.

Three thematic areas were identified to be addressed during the workshop: (1) Sustainable Water Management, (2) Informal Settlements and Sustainable Housing, (3) Urban Health and Well-Being. The three thematic areas represent key components of sustainable cities and priority areas for research. The goal of the workshop was to allow researchers and professionals from the U.S. and Egypt to make connections and establish foundations for future research collaborations.

As the main outcome of the workshop, several teams formed during the workshop working sessions have continued their collaboration developing proposals and joint publications based on the work initiated during the workshop.

  • A proposal focusing on the connection between energy efficiency and urban thermal environments for social housing across Egypt was submitted to the U.S. - Egypt Science and Technology (S&T) Joint Fund .The proposal was a collaboration between Arizona State University, the Military Technical College, and Aswan University.  While this proposal was not successful, this team in addition with Concordia University (Canada) are continuing to look for other joint funding opportunities.This team has also collaborated in joint publications of several articles including: 
  1. Galal, O., H. Mahmoud, D.J. Sailor, 2020TBD. “The impact of urban form on outdoor thermal comfort in hot arid environments during daylight hours, Case Study: New Aswan,” revision submitted for Building and Environment, July.
  2. Galal, O., H. Mahmoud, D.J. Sailor, 2019. “Impact of Evolving Building Morphology on Microclimate in a Hot Arid Climate,” Sustainable Cities and Society, available online 24, Dec, 2019.  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scs.2019.102011 .    
  • A proposal entitled “Integrated Coastal Resiliency Assessment, Adaptation, and Planning”  was submitted to STDF jointly between the Sustainable Smart Cities Research Center at the University of Alabama at Birmingham and several Egyptian colleagues who participated in the NSF Workshop from Alexandria University, Schools of Agriculture and Engineering.
  • As another outcome of this workshop, three universities, MIT, UC Berkeley, and Cairo University are currently working together on a interlinked proposal, bringing in key aspects developed in the NSF International Workshop focused on the Informal Development Trajectory in Egypt. The combination of the three universities has clear research advantages, drawing on the expertise of each and which strongly validates the Workshop efforts in Cairo. The projects are envisioned as developed separately but explicitly linked around a common key theme, but grouping the three allows a comprehensive analysis, broader applicability, and more powerful, relevant and effective directions for the future strategies. The proposed research is envisioned to be initiated in a series of virtual meetings between the US and Egyptian partners, organized by the Sustainable Smart Cities Research Center at the University of Alabama at  Birmingham. The goal of the virtual meetings is to plan and prepare for the follow up workshop that will take place in Egypt on 2021. During this workshop, the field research of the proposal will take place and the structure of the proposal will be develop. Upon return to the U.S., the participants will have follow up virtual meetings to finalize the proposal.
